channel.title: The Christian Science Monitor | USA
channel.description: US national news from The Christian Science Monitor.
channel.copyright: Christian Science Monitor. All rights reserved.

item.title: Free trade or flooding the market? US warns China against surplus exports.
item.description: China and the U.S. share a desire to stabilize relations, but a recent trip by the U.S. treasury secretary highlights trade challenges.
item.dc:creator: Ann Scott Tyson

item.title: How Spanish-language media is fighting for truth this election season
item.description: Latino voters could be a major target for misinformation ahead of the 2024 elections. Combating it means an all-hands-on-deck effort.
item.dc:creator: Christine Fernando and Anita Snow

item.title: Donald Trump outlined his position on abortion. Some conservatives are disappointed.
item.description: After months of scrutiny, former President Donald Trump explained his position on abortion. He says all state decisions must be “the law of the land.”
item.dc:creator: Jill Colvin

item.title: West Virginia U cut majors and faculty. Students fought back – by forming a union.
item.description: West Virginia University students have formed a student union to protest cuts to faculty and curricula. The university is facing a $45 million budget shortfall as it weathers enrollment declines.
item.dc:creator: Leah Willingham

item.title: With the help of community colleges, students in recovery find a fresh start
item.description: Community colleges are increasingly embracing students who are recovering from substance use disorder, creating programs and tackling challenges like funding and staffing.
item.dc:creator: Leah Fabel

item.title: Texas National Guard tests state authority on US southern border
item.description: In response to an increase in illegal border crossings, Texas is trying a new, confrontational approach to using its National Guard.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Matusek
Henry Gass

item.title: Rare East Coast earthquake rocks New York City. How big was it?
item.description: New York’s concrete jungle felt a quake the morning of April 5. Up and down the East Coast 42 million residents reported feeling tremors in the first regional earthquake since 2011.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Peltz

item.title: Sparrows Point helped build the Key Bridge. Its collapse left residents isolated.
item.description: Sparrows Point was a company town that lost its iconic company but persevered. Now, the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge has left residents feeling cut off on the north side of the harbor, wondering what the future may hold.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Hills

item.title: No Labels tried to find a new choice for president. But Haley, Manchin, Christie said no.
item.description: The bipartisan group No Labels said it could capitalize on widespread dissatisfaction with President Joe Biden and Donald Trump by offering voters a moderate option from outside the primary process. But many potential candidates rejected the nomination.
item.dc:creator: Steve Peoples and Jonathan J. Cooper

item.title: Record-setting crowds. Star players. Women’s college basketball has it all.
item.description: Caitlin Clark and Iowa are back in the Final Four again. So are Dawn Staley and undefeated South Carolina.The women’s basketball world will
item.dc:creator: Anne M. Peterson and Doug Feinberg

item.title: Public office isn’t ‘mom-friendly.’ Women lawmakers are changing that.
item.description: Family duties are one reason mothers don’t run for office. Now some are advocating for on-site day care, higher wages, and child care funding.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Babcock

item.title: In US capital, rats thrive where civic trust is low. Here’s how to fix that.
item.description: From the Rose Garden to the Capitol, in the rat battle in the nation’s capital, victory can be measured in civic cooperation, not total destruction.
item.dc:creator: Christa Case Bryant
Sophie Hills

item.title: Math, English, and bright smiles. Traveling dental care in schools fills a gap.
item.description: Nearly half of all U.S. children don’t receive regular dental care, according to a federal report. School-based traveling dental clinics are trying to change that, along with other community health programs and nonprofits.
item.dc:creator: Michael Casey

item.title: The US is seeing a stadium construction boom. Who’s paying for it?
item.description: A proposed sales tax hike to fund stadium projects in Kansas City failed this week at the ballot box. When pro sports teams don’t get the public funds they seek, some double down on a pitch to voters or go to legislators. Others threaten to move.
item.dc:creator: David A. Lieb

item.title: No prescription? No problem. Birth control pills hit shelves.
item.description: Birth control pills are now on sale in the U.S. without a prescription. As states wrestle with abortion, some say this option for women is crucial.
item.dc:creator: Ali Martin

item.title: Trump defied political norms. Now he tests the stock market.
item.description: Some call Trump Media & Technology Group a “meme stock.” But in financial markets, confidence tends to hinge on fundamentals of finance, not the risky ground of emotion or personal trust.
item.dc:creator: Laurent Belsie

item.title: Georgia residents could gain new power to strike fellow voters from the rolls
item.description: Georgia Republicans are seeking further restrictions on who can cast a ballot. Lawmakers passed a bill that allows “vigilante” challenges to large numbers of voter registrations, a move opponents say could see legitimate voters struck from the rolls.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Amy

item.title: Kept on the sidelines, Black assistant basketball coaches want a shot to lead
item.description: Black head coaches are still a rarity in college basketball, despite a growing number of Black coaches rising to the level of assistant coach. Long seen as just recruiters, Black coaches are hoping to take up top posts that don’t change hands often.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Beard

item.title: These local newspapers were struggling. Then student journalists took charge.
item.description: As news deserts grow across the U.S., college newspapers could offer a solution. The Daily Iowan, a student paper for the University of Iowa, bought two struggling local papers which student journalists will help run, in a first-of-its-kind deal.
item.dc:creator: Heather Hollingsworth

item.title: Why drivers may soon pay $15 to use New York’s busiest streets
item.description: New York is the first U.S. city to approve a congestion charge for driving in its busiest districts. Revenues are earmarked for public transit investments.
item.dc:creator: Hillary Chura
